content.webTitle: How Labour MPs got wise to ‘Ed’ the undercover Tory | Diary

fields.headline: Diary: How Labour MPs got wise to ‘Ed’ the undercover Tory
fields.bodyText: • The Labour MPs Gloria De Piero and Jon Ashworth suspected a Tory plant on their seaside express tour, a trip for young Labour activists to meet each other, knock on doors and raise people’s interest in joining the party. A chap calling himself Ed turned up for the day in Lowestoft, from Oxford University, even though they hadn’t advertised at Oxford. Not much else about Ed added up – he didn’t know the other activists from his area, and he asked leading questions as if “trying to get them to say something embarrassing”. He mentioned “central office” and “political A-listers”, Tory terms that aren’t used by the Labour party. But only after his attempt at doorknocking did the MPs have to stifle giggles. “They weren’t interested,” Ed told them. “They said: ‘We don’t want to give the keys back to the people who crashed the car’.” Ashworth said: “At that point I almost burst out laughing – people don’t come out with a perfectly formed political slogan from the opposing party while chatting on a doorstep.” After a bit of Googling, De Piero and Ashworth believe they’ve discovered the real identity of Ed. They believe his real name to be Rupert, but prefer not to embarrass him by revealing his full name. So whoever you are, Rupert, you didn’t quite fool them this time. And if you go undercover again, you might want to have answers to tough questions – such as what your surname is. “Fair play to him for trying,” said Ashworth, “but he was no James Bond.” • Speaking of people who are not James Bond, Nigel Farage has had to dip into Ukip’s grovelling fund yet again, with an apology visit to a Thai constituent and her husband. South East MEP Janice Atkinson was recorded calling mobile food seller Fa Munday a “ting tong from somewhere”. Farage offered “mega, mega apologies” and pleaded with the couple: “Please do not think it’s representative of our people. It jolly well isn’t.” Grouping millions together with infantile sound effects such as “ting tong” or “bongo bongo”? Completely uncharacteristic of Ukip. Mrs Munday’s husband, Vincent, forgivingly says that they remain dedicated Ukip members and are not thinking of leaving. But they’re still no fans of Atkinson: “When she spoke to me on the phone she wasn’t apologetic at all; she was quite belligerent [and] forthright in pointing out what a lovely lady she is.” • Dominique Strauss-Kahn must be feeling humiliated in being the inspiration for the “huffing, puffing and bottom-slapping” sexual predator in the film Welcome to New York, portrayed in plain grotesqueness by Gérard Depardieu. But if you feel a twinge of pity for old DSK, glance over the figures released by his consulting company, Parnasse: last year the company made a profit of nearly €766,000, of which he has taken €700,000 as a “dividend”. Marianne magazine in Paris says that a mere half-hour consultancy with DSK costs €50,000. Heftier than a post-pudding Depardieu. • After 15 years online, the news-aggregating website Fark has announced guidelines to ban misogyny from its comments section. Founder Drew Curtis announced on the site: “If the internet was a dude, we’d all agree that dude has a serious problem with women.” The site will no longer admit “rape jokes”, terminology such as “‘whores” or “sluts”, or “suggesting that a woman who suffered a crime was somehow asking for it”. Slate.com flagged up how commenters are trying to slither around the rules: “We need to stay under the radar: minx, coquette, hussy, etc.” It’s a brave move from Curtis on a site with an 88% male readership – but in the same spirit he might want to consider changing his own bio: “Drew runs Fark. Drew likes boobies and beer. That’s pretty much it.” At least the picture only contains him and a beer. • A 15-year-old’s tweet gained a lot of attention early this morning after being retweeted by Richard Dawkins. She asked the atheist writer: “Do you think it’s right that at my New Zealand high school, we get detentions for not bowing our heads during the prayer?” Dawkins didn’t give his take on it, but plenty of others have, including @AtheistStoned, who quipped: “How do they know?”
